soc.message

Class SOCPlayerElement

  • java.lang.Object
    • soc.message.SOCMessage
      • soc.message.SOCMessageForGame
        • soc.message.SOCPlayerElement
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable

    public class SOCPlayerElement
extends SOCMessageForGame
    This message from the server conveys one part of a player's status, such as their number of settlements remaining.

    Unless otherwise mentioned, any getElementType() can be sent with any action (SET, GAIN, LOSE).

    Message Sequence:

    • For a bank trade (server response to player's SOCBankTrade), all the LOSE messages come before the GAINs.
    • For trade between players (SOCAcceptOffer), the LOSEs and GAINs are interspersed to simplify server code.
    • For dice rolls, after SOCDiceResult any clients older than v2.0.00 are sent GAIN for each resource type gained by each player from the roll. Newer clients are instead sent SOCDiceResultResources. Afterwards the current player (any client version) is sent their currently held amounts for each resource as a group of SOCPlayerElement(pn, SET, ...) messages.
    • Most other situations send single PlayerElement messages or their sequence doesn't matter.

    Resource loss can be expected and good (buying pieces or trading with other players) or unexpected and bad (monopoly, robber, discards). v1.2.00 and newer have sound effects to announce unexpected gains or losses; to help recognize this, this message type gets a new flag field isNews(). Versions older than v1.2.00 ignore the new field.

    To use less overhead to send multiple similar element changes, use SOCPlayerElements instead; doing so requires client version 2.0.00 or newer.

    For some game events/actions, for efficiency and to help bots understand the event (since they aren't sent SOCGameServerTexts), newer client versions are sent a more specific message instead of several SOCPlayerElement and SOCGameServerTexts:

    • SOCDiceResultResources: v2.0.00 and newer
    • SOCReportRobbery: v2.4.50 and newer
    Author:
    Robert S Thomas
    See Also:
    SOCGameElements, Serialized Form

    • Field Detail

      • VERSION_FOR_CARD_ELEMENTS

        public static final int VERSION_FOR_CARD_ELEMENTS
        First version number (2.0.00) that has element types replacing single-purpose message types: SOCPlayerElement.PEType.RESOURCE_COUNT, SOCPlayerElement.PEType.PLAYED_DEV_CARD_FLAG, SOCPlayerElement.PEType.LAST_SETTLEMENT_NODE. Send older clients SOCSetPlayedDevCard or other appropriate messages instead.

        Same version as SOCPlayerElements.MIN_VERSION and SOCDevCardAction.VERSION_FOR_MULTIPLE.

        Since:
        2.0.00
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Constructor Detail

      • SOCPlayerElement

        public SOCPlayerElement(java.lang.String gameName,
                        int pn,
                        int ac,
                        int et,
                        int amt)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Create a PlayerElement message with an int element type.
        Parameters:
        gameName - name of the game
        pn - the player number; v1.1.19 and newer allow -1 for some elements (applies to board or to all players). Earlier client versions will throw an exception accessing player -1. If the element type allows -1, its constant's javadoc will mention that.
        ac - the type of action: SET, GAIN, or LOSE. Do not use GAIN_NEWS, SET_NEWS, or LOSE_NEWS here, call SOCPlayerElement(String, int, int, int, int, boolean) instead.
        et - SOCPlayerElement.PEType.getValue() for the type of element, such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.SETTLEMENTS or SOCPlayerElement.PEType.WHEAT. For playing pieces in general, see elementTypeForPieceType(int).
        amt - the amount to set or change the element
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if ac is GAIN_NEWS, SET_NEWS, or LOSE_NEWS
        See Also:
        SOCPlayerElement(String, int, int, PEType, int), SOCPlayerElement(String, int, int, int, int, boolean)

      • SOCPlayerElement

        public SOCPlayerElement(java.lang.String gameName,
                        int pn,
                        int ac,
                        SOCPlayerElement.PEType et,
                        int amt)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Create a PlayerElement message with a SOCPlayerElement.PEType element type.
        Parameters:
        gameName - name of the game
        pn - the player number; v1.1.19 and newer allow -1 for some elements (applies to board or to all players). Earlier client versions will throw an exception accessing player -1. If the element type allows -1, its constant's javadoc will mention that.
        ac - the type of action: SET, GAIN, or LOSE. Do not use GAIN_NEWS, SET_NEWS, or LOSE_NEWS here, call SOCPlayerElement(String, int, int, int, int, boolean) instead.
        et - the type of element, such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.SETTLEMENTS or SOCPlayerElement.PEType.WHEAT. For playing pieces in general, see elementTypeForPieceType(int).
        amt - the amount to set or change the element
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if ac is GAIN_NEWS, SET_NEWS, or LOSE_NEWS
        Since:
        2.3.00
        See Also:

      • SOCPlayerElement

        public SOCPlayerElement(java.lang.String gameName,
                        int pn,
                        int ac,
                        SOCPlayerElement.PEType et,
                        int amt,
                        boolean isNews)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Create a PlayerElement message, optionally with the isNews() flag set.
        Parameters:
        gameName - name of the game
        pn - the player number; v1.1.19 and newer allow -1 for some elements (applies to board or to all players). Earlier client versions will throw an exception accessing player -1. If the element type allows -1, its constant's javadoc will mention that.
        ac - the type of action: SET, GAIN, or LOSE. Do not use GAIN_NEWS, SET_NEWS, or LOSE_NEWS here, instead set isNews parameter.
        et - the type of element, such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.SETTLEMENTS or SOCPlayerElement.PEType.WHEAT. For playing pieces in general, see elementTypeForPieceType(int).
        amt - the amount to set or change the element
        isNews - Value to give the isNews() flag
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if ac is GAIN_NEWS, SET_NEWS or LOSE_NEWS
        Since:
        2.3.00
        See Also:
        SOCPlayerElement(String, int, int, PEType, int), SOCPlayerElement(String, int, int, int, int, boolean)

      • SOCPlayerElement

        public SOCPlayerElement(java.lang.String gameName,
                        int seatNumber,
                        int actionType,
                        int elementType,
                        int amt,
                        boolean isNews)
                 throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Create a PlayerElement message, optionally with the isNews() flag set.
        Parameters:
        gameName - name of the game
        seatNumber - the player number; v1.1.19 and newer allow -1 for some elements (applies to board or to all players). Earlier client versions will throw an exception accessing player -1. If the element type allows -1, its constant's javadoc will mention that.
        actionType - the type of action: SET, GAIN, or LOSE. Do not use GAIN_NEWS, SET_NEWS, or LOSE_NEWS here, instead set isNews parameter.
        elementType - SOCPlayerElement.PEType.getValue() for the type of element, such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.SETTLEMENTS or SOCPlayerElement.PEType.WHEAT. For playing pieces in general, see elementTypeForPieceType(int).
        amt - the amount to set or change the element
        isNews - Value to give the isNews() flag
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if ac is GAIN_NEWS, SET_NEWS or LOSE_NEWS
        Since:
        1.2.00
        See Also:
        SOCPlayerElement(String, int, int, PEType, int, boolean), SOCPlayerElement(String, int, int, int, int)

    • Method Detail

      • elementTypeForPieceType

        public static SOCPlayerElement.PEType elementTypeForPieceType(int ptype)
        Get the element type to send for a given SOCPlayingPiece type.

        Before v2.3.00 this returned an int.

        Parameters:
        ptype - Playing piece type constant, such as SOCPlayingPiece.SETTLEMENT
        Returns:
        ptype's element type for this message, such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.SETTLEMENTS, or SOCPlayerElement.PEType.UNKNOWN_TYPE
        Since:
        2.0.00

      • getPlayerNumber

        public int getPlayerNumber()
        Get this element's player number.

        v1.1.19 and newer allow -1 for some elements (applies to board or to all players). Earlier client versions will throw an exception accessing player -1. If the element type allows -1, its constant's javadoc will mention that.

        Returns:
        the player number

      • getAction

        public int getAction()
        Get the type of action.
        Returns:
        the action type: SET, GAIN, or LOSE

      • getElementType

        public int getElementType()
        Get the element type, the type of info that is changing. This is an int to preserve values from unknown types from different versions. converted at sending side with SOCPlayerElement.PEType.getValue(). To convert at receiving side to a SOCPlayerElement.PEType, use SOCPlayerElement.PEType.valueOf(int).
        Returns:
        the element type, such as SOCPlayerElement.PEType.SETTLEMENTS or SOCPlayerElement.PEType.NUMKNIGHTS, as int

      • getAmount

        public int getAmount()
        Get the new value to set, or the delta amount to gain/lose.
        Returns:
        the amount to SET, GAIN, or LOSE

        Before v2.0.00 this method was getValue().

      • isNews

        public boolean isNews()
        Is this element change notably good or an unexpected bad change or loss? For example, resource lost to the robber or monopoly or gained from the fog hex.

        Do not set this flag if the player is expecting the gain or loss. For example, if this message is server's response to their chosen resources in a Discovery, Monopoly, or Gold Hex gain dialog.

        If getAction() == SET, treat message as bad news.

        This flag is ignored by clients older than v1.2.00.

        Returns:
        True if marked "news", false otherwise
        Since:
        1.2.00

        public java.lang.String toCmd()

        public static SOCPlayerElement parseDataStr(java.lang.String s)
        Parse the command String into a PlayerElement message
        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • stripAttribNames

        public static java.lang.String stripAttribNames(java.lang.String messageStrParams)
        Strip out the parameter/attribute names from toString()'s format, returning message parameters as a comma-delimited list for SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String). Undoes mapping of action constant integers -> strings ("GAIN" etc).
        Parameters:
        messageStrParams - Params part of a message string formatted by toString(); not null
        Returns:
        Message parameters without attribute names, or null if params are malformed
        Since:
        2.4.50

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Description copied from class: SOCMessage
        Simple human-readable delimited representation, used for debug purposes: SOCPutPiece:game=test5|playerNumber=3|pieceType=0|coord=40a
        Could also be used by a SOCServer.recordGameEvent(String, SOCMessage) implementation.

        Within this representation, message parameters should be in same order used by SOCMessage.toCmd() and parseDataStr(..). Should be parseable by SOCMessage.parseMsgStr(String) which calls SOCMessage.stripAttribNames(String), which your class can override if needed.

        Overrides:
        toString in class SOCMessageForGame
        Returns:
        a human readable form of the message
        See Also:
        SOCMessage.toCmd()
